children.text: "The Road Not Taken" is a narrative poem by Robert Frost, first published in the August 1915 issue of the
Atlantic Monthly
, and later published as the first poem in the 1916 poetry collection,
Mountain Interval

. Its central theme is the divergence of paths, both literally and figuratively, although its interpretation is noted for being complex and potentially controversial. The controversy of the poem's interpretation stems from the fact that the poem is conventionally understood as a testament to individualism, the virtue of self-reliance, and the reward that awaits those who strike out boldly on their own, regardless of common belief and the pull of the crowd. Indeed, the poem often appears in such wishful terms as a feature of corporate sloganeering, trite self-help sentiment, or the wisdom of the aged mentor.

Indeed, Frost’s “The Road Not Taken” is one of the most frequently misinterpreted poems in American literature. At first glance, it appears to champion non-conformity and individualism, a reading that aligns with the commonly quoted lines: “I took the one less traveled by, / And that has made all the difference” (Frost 19–20). However, a deeper analysis reveals a more complex meditation on choice, regret, and the human tendency to ascribe meaning to arbitrary decisions.

The poem opens with the speaker standing at a fork in a yellow wood, confronted by two diverging paths. Frost spent the years 1912 to 1915 in England, where among his acquaintances was the writer Edward Thomas. Thomas and Frost became close friends and took many walks together. One day, as they were walking together, they came across two roads. Thomas was indecisive about which road to take, and in retrospect often lamented that they should have taken the other one. After Frost returned to New Hampshire in 1915, he sent Thomas an advance copy of "The Road Not Taken." Frost said he intended the poem as a kind of a joke.

The poem consists of four stanzas of five lines each. With the rhyme scheme as ABAAB, the first line rhymes with the third and fourth, and the second line rhymes with the fifth. The meter is iambic tetrameter, with each line having four two-syllable feet, though in almost every line, in different positions, an iamb is replaced with an anapest. "The Road Not Taken," then, reads colloquially, beginning as a kind of photographic depiction of a quiet moment in yellow wood. The variation of its rhythm gives naturalness, a feeling of thought occurring spontaneously, affecting the reader's sense of expectation. The poem’s ABAAB rhyme scheme offers a sense of cohesion, contrasting with the uncertainty of the speaker’s decision. Scholar Frank Lentricchia notes, “Frost’s language mimics the natural cadences of speech, but beneath this surface lies a formal precision that mirrors the internal conflict of the speaker” (Lentricchia 102).

That internal conflict stems, however, not from the decision to be made, but how the story will be told about that moment. A careful reading of the poem reveals, specifically in lines 9-12, that the speaker could see no real difference between the two roads, and that the choice of one over the other was merely, in the moment, an entirely arbitrary decision:
Though as for that the passing there
Had worn them really about the same,
And both that morning equally lay
In leaves no step had trodden black. (Frost 9-12)

The point of the poem is that the speaker anticipates, however, that in his later years he will offer a romantic revisioning of that moment, narrating his decision as a moment of exceptional individualism: "I shall be telling this with a sigh / Somewhere ages and ages hence," he tells us, in a false claim that his choice has "made all the difference" in his life. As literary critic David Orr argues, “The poem isn’t a salute to can-do individualism. It’s a commentary on the self-deception we practice when constructing the story of our lives” (Orr 74). The speaker initially acknowledges the similarity between the two roads but later reconstructs his choice as significant—suggesting a desire to impose order and meaning on life’s ambiguity. "The Road Not Taken," then, is much less a poem about bold individualism and much more a poem about how we retrospectively reconstruct the events of our past in order to feature ourselves as tha e heroes of our life story. Another important aspect is the poem’s retrospective perspective. The final stanza begins, “I shall be telling this with a sigh / Somewhere ages and ages hence” (Frost 16–17), indicating that the speaker is not recounting the moment of choice, but imagining how he will remember it in the future. This temporal layering highlights the role of narrative in shaping personal identity. As Seamus Heaney observes, Frost presents “a drama of the self, playing out in the interstices between action and reflection” (Heaney 58).

The poem, it might be said, is a poem about lying, and Frost's performance of the poem some fifty years after it's publication underlines that interpretation. One imagines, perhaps, that after a century of misreadings, Frost sought in his rendition of the poem to set the record straight. Indeed, the versioning of the poem as a record of vocal performance is in keeping with Charles Bernstein's contention that

"The Road Not Taken" reads colloquially, beginning as a kind of photographic depiction of a quiet moment in yellow wood. The variation of its rhythm gives naturalness, a feeling of thought occurring spontaneously, affecting the reader's sense of expectation. Lines 9-12, cited above, the few lines containing strictly iambs, the more regular rhythm supports the idea of a turning towards an acceptance of a kind of reality: "Though as for that the passing there … " In the final line, the way the rhyme and rhythm work together is significantly different, and catches the reader off guard.

In Frost's performance of the poem, recorded almost half a century later, one notes his divergence from the strict formal patterns of the poem--particularly in those lines in which he switches from the high rhetorical oration of the poem's meditative reminiscences to the much more conversational (indeed, almost a whispered aside) in which he confesses that there was, in fact, no real difference between the two roads apparent to the speaker. As the following annotations indicate, Frost's reading of the poem is marked consistently by slow tempo and pronounced caesura, in a recitation that any listener would recognize as a classic version of "poet voice" as Marit MacArthur would name it. However, from 00:24 to 00:34, Frost descends into a high tempo, conversational voice as he reveals the truth of the moment.

In conclusion, “The Road Not Taken” offers a nuanced exploration of human decision-making. Far from a straightforward celebration of individualism, it reveals the psychological mechanisms through which people justify their choices. Frost’s poem serves as a reminder that the stories we tell ourselves about our lives may matter more than the actual events that inspired them.

A more charitable way to read this poem--that is, other than it being a poem about how we all lie about ourselves--is that Frost is actually celebrating the social and cultural function of poetry as an act of memorialization and celebration. His shift in tone, from poet voice to conversation and back again, accentuates and demonstrates the power of poetic diction and, indeed, decades of misreading testify to that very power.

Orr, David. The Road Not Taken: Finding America in the Poem Everyone Loves and Almost Everyone Gets Wrong. Penguin, 2015.
